sections.content: Forget what you've heard about needing 3-6 months of expenses saved up. That's the destination, not the starting line. Right now, we're focused on one number: $500. That's your Starter Emergency Fund, and it's going to change how you sleep at night.

Research from the Federal Reserve shows that $500 covers the vast majority of common emergencies:

• Car repair: $200-$500
• Urgent plumbing fix: $150-$400
• Unexpected medical copay: $50-$250
• Replacement appliance: $200-$500
• Emergency travel: $200-$400

With $500 in the bank, you can handle most of life's curveballs without touching a credit card.

Here's the plan to get there:

1. Open a separate savings account (even a basic one). Keeping emergency money separate from spending money is crucial — out of sight, out of temptation.

2. Set a weekly savings amount. Even $20/week gets you to $500 in 25 weeks — about 6 months.

3. Boost it with windfalls. Tax refund? Birthday money? Sell something you don't use? Every lump sum gets you there faster.

sections.content: Important rule: Your emergency fund is NOT for sales, treats, or 'I deserve this' moments. It's for genuine emergencies only. When you use it (and you will — that's what it's for), your first priority is building it back up.
$500 in a separate account. That's your first safety net. It won't cover everything, but it covers most things — and that peace of mind is priceless.
Most people never start because the 'right' number feels too far away. But you're starting with $500, and that's brilliant. Small, achievable targets build unstoppable momentum!
